results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 27]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows John and Marie’s honeymoon on Hayman Island in Queensland. They travel up through New South Wales and Queensland, passing through Tamworth, Surfers Paradise and Brisbane, before taking a seaplane to the Whitsundays. The film has excellent footage of summer holidays with friends, fishing, playing tennis, swimming, and exploring the island and resorts.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 title cards ‘Hayman Island’, ‘Produced and Photographed by John R. Anderson’
00:00:18:00 1950s cars driving down a busy main street
00:01:19:00 kids playing and people swimming at a local pool
00:01:54:00 Tamworth town centre featuring the Tudor Hotel
00:02:05:00 driving down a street lined with jacaranda trees
00:03:04:00 banana plants
00:03:34:00 the exterior of the Café Cathay in Surfers Paradise
00:03:50:00 Brisbane City Hall
00:04:29:00 sign for ‘The Oasis: Queensland’s Most Beautiful Garden’
00:05:00:00 boys on a diving board above a beautiful pool
00:05:45:00 catching a seaplane to the Whitsundays with some beautiful footage over the water
00:09:35:00 two women looking out over the coastline from a cliff
00:10:15:00 at the resort, by the pool with striped umbrellas and deckchairs
00:11:10:00 group of friends in holiday attire
00:11:31:00 man carrying a large fish, very pleased with his catch
00:11:58:00 holidaymakers lined up for a group shot
00:13:00:00 time at the beach
00:14:38:00 searching for oysters
00:14:50:00 another catch – a swordfish
00:15:08:00 game of tennis in bathers
00:16:40:00 on a boat, exploring the island
00:18:50:00 Melbourne Bitter Ale and Cairns Bitter Ale beer bottles
00:19:55:00 shells at a shell shop
00:21:28:00 cooking a picnic on an open fire at the beach
00:22:00:00 new people arriving on a boat
00:22:57:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 26]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows a family holiday to sunny Surfers Paradise, Queensland. The family visit the theme parks Ski Land and Marineland, which combined to become Sea World in 1972. The film features some great holiday footage of the motel pool, theme parks and the beach at Surfers Paradise, along with notable 70s fashion.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 motel sign ‘Surfside 6: Holiday – Overnight’
00:00:19:00 kids playing in the motel pool
00:03:07:00 enjoying milkshakes and icy-poles
00:03:27:00 on a chairlift
00:04:35:00 water skiiers doing tricks at Ski Land
00:07:06:00 a pyramid of people on water skis carrying flags reading ‘Ski Land’
00:08:28:00 dolphins performing tricks in a pool at Marineland
00:09:33:00 a trainer and a girl in a bikini holding out a fish on a platform over the pool for a dolphin who leaps into the air; the trainer pushes the girl into the water
00:11:10:00 riding on three-person bikes called ‘Silly Cycles’
00:12:26:00 The Sands Hotel
00:13:53:00 rainbow lorikeets
00:14:30:00 riding on a toy train around the park grounds
00:15:00:00 boarding an ANSETT plane

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 - Indigo
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 – Indigo was broadcast as the sixth of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Force Fed (Stuart McCormick & Michael Brand), Magnetic Head Circuit (Chubba, Matt Bastard, Peter Randall), Antartica, Future, Wake up Return 2 Heart, Rave Safe Info (Melissa Dent & Michael Arnold), Air Fiction (Andy Taylor), Steve Law (Zen Paradox), Tom Cia, Derek ‘Chill’ Shiel and The Visitor (Andrew Till).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 – Indigo is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 5 - Blue
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 5 – Blue was broadcast as the fifth of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Adem Jaffers (Tekno Mandala), Space Between the Gaps (Paul Gafney), Dale Nasonand Kim Bounds (abcTVxyz), Dale Nason and Troy Innocent (Cyber Dada), 1x4x9 (Braden Schlager & Miles du Heaume), Video Graffiti (Andrew Nelson), ABCTVXYZ, Surfis (Dom Owen and Peter Bourke), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton) and The Visitor (Andrew Till).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 5 - Blue is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Kodak Movie Light and two bulbs
results.brief_description: “Kodak Movie light 220 x 140V 1000W V/XS/200 label on reverse says: do not earth. double insulation. On and Off switch: 250V A.C. only. ELMACO Australian plug: Peaston, 250V 7.5A V/A50/1 Two - Philips Photolita bulbs in their original boxes. Photolita* trademark PF218E 43 Photolita - NM 250V 500W C8 Made in Holland With one instruction pamphlet which has guide numbers of the exposure times.”

details.label: Measurements
display_values: Arms are adjustable. When at right angles to each side: 265 x 565 x 123 mm. When arms are brought in to minimum: 265 x 125 x 123 mm. cord length from base of light to tip of plug: 2600 mm Bulb: 150mm x 110 x 110 mm (each) original box: 163 x 118 x 120 mm Instruction booklet: 147 x 137 mm

results.title: Assorted Film Making Accessories
results.brief_description: “Coated Walz Filter for Color Film housed in original cardboard box. Walz brand clear plastic case with lid and base. Metal rimmed light brown/orange glass lens. Instructions included Kodak Kodachrome 25 colour movie film daylight for 8mm roll (7.5m KM459P) Tin can embossed with Kodak logo on the top. Unused reel of film. Tin sealed together with black duct tape. Original box Envelope Instructions Film price includes processing by Kodak. Mailing envelope enclosed (this has never been used and is folded in a small square) 7.5 metres in length of douible 8mm film on this roll which is intended to yield 15 metres in length of 8mm movies. The additional film at each end serves as leader and trailer for light protection and camera loading. Process before Oct 1979. KM459P CAT 416 9918 Daylight, ASA 25, 15 DIN 2 pairs of mono ear buds to be plugged in to a crystal radio. 1. Brown leather pouch with pink ear bud. 2. Black vinyl puch with cream ear bud. Sunbeam lens brush. Sundry cord in ziplock bag. National brand. Could possibly have been a cord to connect flash. However there doesn’t see to be a donated item which this pairs with. Cyldon brand film reel. (for 8mm) Light metal (tin?). Made in England Markers for 50, 100, 150 and 200 feet.”

KM459P CAT 416 9918 Daylight, ASA 25, 15 DIN 2 pairs of mono ear buds to be plugged in to a crystal radio. 1. Brown leather pouch with pink ear bud. 2. Black vinyl puch with cream ear bud. Sunbeam lens brush. Sundry cord in ziplock bag. National brand. Could possibly have been a cord to connect flash. However there doesn’t see to be a donated item which this pairs with. Cyldon brand film reel. (for 8mm) Light metal (tin?). Made in England Markers for 50, 100, 150 and 200 feet.”
description_for_label: “Coated Walz Filter for Color Film housed in original cardboard box. Walz brand clear plastic case with lid and base. Metal rimmed light brown/orange glass lens. Instructions included Kodak Kodachrome 25 colour movie film daylight for 8mm roll (7.5m KM459P) Tin can embossed with Kodak logo on the top. Unused reel of film. Tin sealed together with black duct tape. Original box Envelope Instructions Film price includes processing by Kodak. Mailing envelope enclosed (this has never been used and is folded in a small square) 7.5 metres in length of douible 8mm film on this roll which is intended to yield 15 metres in length of 8mm movies. The additional film at each end serves as leader and trailer for light protection and camera loading. Process before Oct 1979. KM459P CAT 416 9918 Daylight, ASA 25, 15 DIN 2 pairs of mono ear buds to be plugged in to a crystal radio. 1. Brown leather pouch with pink ear bud. 2. Black vinyl puch with cream ear bud. Sunbeam lens brush. Sundry cord in ziplock bag. National brand. Could possibly have been a cord to connect flash. However there doesn’t see to be a donated item which this pairs with. Cyldon brand film reel. (for 8mm) Light metal (tin?). Made in England Markers for 50, 100, 150 and 200 feet.”
